title: Parenthood!!!
content:
Okay... get this; there are government officials who say that parents are not the main contributor in a child's education; and that the government should be the one who trains children, and that parents cannot refuse to allow a child to take part in extra-curricular activities; this is plain ludocrous!!!

What do you think? Should parents raise their children, or the government?Proud Leader of the "Tough Guys Wear Pink" Society

title: Re: Parenthood!!!
content:
There is an interesting mathematical theorem that describes why some people are homeless, and always will be. It also explains Bill Gates.

If a population is started off equal, with equal amounts of something [lets call it poon] and an equal ability to engage with others and transfer poon between themselves and others, after just a few iterations there appears an interesting distribution; it is like the normal distribution but skewed towards the top and assymetric. It results in a few poon poor, some not so poor, a middle class, an upper class and a few really really poon rich people.

If you place a restraint on the system to either reduce the number of rich or try to eliminate the poor, the distribution skews, but there are always some rich and some destitute. [Rich can be totally eliminated if you kill them when the earn over a certain amount, but oddly this doesn't work for poor.]

It is thus a new and controversial theory that rich and poor are inevitable consequences of society and that all we can do is try to help, but never solve the problem permanently. [You should still help out poor countries; their entire distribution needs input.] Certain people hate this idea because they'd like to think that if everyone helped out and held hands all our problems would dissapear. Certain people love it because now nothing is thier fault, its inevitable. Both are stupid.

A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

title: Re: Parenthood!!!
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Quote:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
At any rate, it is the parents right to chose thier child's education. I think the child should be allowed to divorce their parents if they are severely limiting their potential, however.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------



Whoa!!! Steady!!!

Imagian that were true. You'd have millions of teens on the streets. I would agree if the parents were abusing their children, but like 85% of all teens hate their parents anyways... that would be America's free ticket to become a third world country, and would have such a high homeless rate, due to the fact that the only public services around would be McDonalds.[hr][/quote]

It would probably be more of a deterrent than anything.

[quote]Quote:[hr]There is an interesting mathematical theorem that describes why some people are homeless, and always will be. It also explains Bill Gates.

If a population is started off equal, with equal amounts of something [lets call it poon] and an equal ability to engage with others and transfer poon between themselves and others, after just a few iterations there appears an interesting distribution; it is like the normal distribution but skewed towards the top and assymetric. It results in a few poon poor, some not so poor, a middle class, an upper class and a few really really poon rich people.

It is thus a new and controversial theory that rich and poor are inevitable consequences of society and that all we can do is try to help, but never solve the problem permanently. [You should still help out poor countries; their entire distribution needs input.] Certain people hate this idea because they'd like to think that if everyone helped out and held hands all our problems would dissapear. Certain people love it because now nothing is thier fault, its inevitable. Both are stupid.[hr][/quote]

No way that's purely mathematical. There has to be some sociological factor in this. If "everyone just helped out and helds hands", or if we really started "with equal amounts of something [lets call it poon] and an equal ability to engage with others and transfer poon", the long run equilibrium would probably end up at the equal distribution point. But, out of curiosity, what theorem is this?[quote]Quote:[hr]Just remember that this is the year of the elite devil.

1337 + 666 = 2003[hr][/quote]

title: Re: Parenthood!!!
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]No way that's purely mathematical. There has to be some sociological factor in this. If "everyone just helped out and helds hands", or if we really started "with equal amounts of something [lets call it poon] and an equal ability to engage with others and transfer poon", the long run equilibrium would probably end up at the equal distribution point. But, out of curiosity, what theorem is this?[hr][/quote]

Published in September's New Scientist it is the result of a three year mathematical study into complex systems; I'll see if I can get you the paper title.

However the authors state that this is not a complete description of the problem and that the mathematical component is not a complete and determinitave variable; the best results were obtained when everyone did indeed help each other out, and if the simulation was profit oriented things got a lot worse quicker.

The main point of the study however was to show that even if everything were perfect, there would still be rich and poor; the bufferings of chance would see to that. Like in a pond, although the surface would be smooth, below it there would be constant movement; canstant random variation, and because of that some would end badly, others well off.

A proud member of the Spleen Extinction society

title: Re: Parenthood!!!
content:
Take from the rich and give to the poor? I'm sure you are all familiar with the Communist system of government, and if the government start messing around with the American peole's money that's what it will become.
I really like LordofGlobox's post last post. America's government was not intended to be a charity or to specialize in handouts. Did Bill Gates earn his money? If he did, then the government can't just take it. Did Donald Trump earn his money? Then the government can't take it! This is one reason why I think property taxes is so bad. The government has no right to tax YOUR property. I think what we all forget is that WE are the United State of America, not the government. Actually, the government was designed for three purposes, and three only as shown in the constitution.
1: Preserve (as in preserving the system of government,etc.
2:Protect (from people like terrorists,etc.)
3:Promote the general welfare (not meaning take thir property, give big handouts, and dictate our lives)

Well, that's how it is written, and too much has changed (that's how I see it anyhow!!)
